unnormalised: So, someone asked how Indians usually handle online payments, especially on e-commerce sites? Well, it's a mix of everything these days! Back when I started using the internet, like, maybe around '08-'09, it was mostly COD, ya know, Cash on Delivery. People were wary of putting their card details online.
normalised: So, someone asked how Indians usually handle online payments, especially on e-commerce sites? Well, it is a mix of everything these days! Back when I started using the internet, like, maybe around two thousand eight to two thousand nine, it was mostly C-O-D, ya know, Cash on Delivery. People were wary of putting their card details online.

unnormalised: But times have changed, bhai! Now, UPI (Unified Payments Interface) is HUGE. Apps like PhonePe, Google Pay, and Paytm are everywhere. You just scan a QR code or enter a UPI ID and boom, payment done! Super convenient for smaller transactions, like buying chai for Rs. 20 at a roadside stall or paying Rs. 250 for auto fare. Almost everyone uses UPI now.
normalised: But times have changed, bhai! Now, U-P-I (Unified Payments Interface) is HUGE. Apps like PhonePe, Google Pay, and Paytm are everywhere. You just scan a Q-R code or enter a U-P-I I-D and boom, payment done! Super convenient for smaller transactions, like buying chai for rupee twenty at a roadside stall or paying rupee two hundred and fifty for auto fare. Almost everyone uses U-P-I now.

unnormalised: Credit and debit cards are still popular, especially for bigger purchases like electronics or that fancy saree you saw online costing Rs. 5000. Net banking is also used, though maybe not as much as UPI. You'll often see options like ICICI net banking or HDFC net banking on e-commerce sites. Wallets like Mobikwik are also there, but they are not as widely used as UPI apps, to be honest.

unnormalised: E-commerce sites often offer discounts for using certain payment methods. Like, you might get 5% off (max Rs. 200) if you use an Axis Bank credit card. Or you might get some cashback on paying through Paytm wallet if the total purchase is Rs. 1000 or more. So, it is a smart move to check the payment options available before checking out!
normalised: E-commerce sites often offer discounts for using certain payment methods. Like, you might get five percent off (maximum rupee two hundred) if you use an Axis Bank credit card. Or you might get some cashback on paying through Paytm wallet if the total purchase is rupee one thousand or more. So, it is a smart move to check the payment options available before checking out!

unnormalised: Basically, it's all about convenience and what people are comfortable with. UPI's simplicity has made it the king, but other methods still have their place. And with the ever-increasing number of online shoppers in India, the payment scene is only going to get more interesting!
